item.title: Invoke-RestMethod with anti-forgery tokens in header and cookie
item.description: To help prevent cross-site scripting attacks some websites uses anti-forgery tokens. If you would like to talk to a REST API which uses this security measure you might run into problems if you are trying to use the PowerShell cmdlet Invoke-RestMethod. I have seen some people suggesting that Invoke-RestMethod does not have support for this, which is not true. It’s just a little bit more complicated than expected. What’s needed is basically a custom header and a cookie.

item.title: How to use splatting in PowerShell
item.description: I still hear a lot of people who don’t know how splatting works in Powershell. Splatting was introduced in Powershell 2.0 so it has been around for a while and it can make scripts look more clean and easy to read. This is how Microsoft explains splatting: Splatting is a method of passing a collection of parameter values to a command as unit. Windows PowerShell associates each value in the collection with a command parameter.
